thread.title: Lovingood: Airport deal will spur regional, local economy
thread.title_full: Lovingood: Airport deal will spur regional, local economy

author: Staff and wire reports
title: Lovingood: Airport deal will spur regional, local economy
text: Lovingood: Airport deal will spur regional, local economy Comment By Staff and submitted reports VVdailypress.com By Staff and submitted reports Posted Aug. 6, 2015 at 2:23 PM By Staff and submitted reports Posted Aug. 6, 2015 at 2:23 PM » Social News ONTARIO — Officials announced Thursday that Los Angeles will hand control of Ontario International Airport back to the city of Ontario, a move that San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors Vice Chairman Robert Lovingood says will provide a "powerful boost" to the county’s economy, with "side benefits" to Southern California Logistics Airport and the High Desert. "This is one of the critical components to ensure Inland Empire's continued economic recovery and continued growth,” said Lovingood, whose 1st District includes much of the High Desert. “This further ensures that our two-county region, the City of Ontario and other inland cities will become the desired areas within Southern California to live, work and play.” Air service and passenger traffic at Ontario has plummeted to levels not seen since the 1980s, and Lovingood's office says the Inland Empire has taken a tremendous economic hit over the last several years because of it. With the airport run by Los Angeles' airport agency, which also controls LAX, Lovingood says a "severe decline in activity has cost our region $400 million annually and 8,000 jobs." “Once this airport transition is complete, I fully expect ONT to see tremendous growth in terms of added flights, passenger traffic and job growth,” Lovingood said. “That will naturally generate activity and growth at Southern California Logistics Airport in Victorville. SCLA is already home to large commercial operators like Boeing, Pratt & Whitney, and General Electric. SCLA is designed for international air cargo and heavy maintenance, with an extended 15,050-foot runway and does not have the airspace problems of other Southern California airports.” Lovingood praised efforts by Ontario City Council Member Alan D. Wapner and Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti, as well as the county and San Bernardino Associated Governments, in advocating for local control of the airport. San Bernardino County is a member of the Ontario International Airport Authority. The county has been working with the Congressional delegation and local stakeholders to aggressively advocate for legislation, Lovingood said. By Staff and submitted reports VVdailypress.com By Staff and submitted reports Posted Aug. 6, 2015 at 2:23 PM » Comment or view comments " data-width="650" data-numposts="20" data-colorscheme="light"> » STAY INFORMED
